Package mz.intro.introDPQ

Class IntroDPQSmoothHeap

java.lang.Object
mz.SortComparable
mz.Heap
mz.SmoothHeap
mz.intro.IntroSmoothHeap
mz.intro.introDPQ.IntroDPQSmoothHeap
All Implemented Interfaces:
HeapInterface<Comparable>, InsertionInterface<Comparable>, Intro<Comparable>, IntroDPQ<Comparable>, QuickInterface<Comparable>, Sort<Comparable>, SortSwap<Comparable>
public class IntroDPQSmoothHeap extends IntroSmoothHeap implements IntroDPQ<Comparable>
IntroDPQ (Dual Pivot Quick) Smooth Heap Sort is a hybrid sorting algorithm that combines the strengths of Dual Pivot Quick Sort and Smooth Heap Sort. It aims to provide fast average-case performance while maintaining worst-case guarantees. The basic idea behind Intro Sort is to start with Dual Pivot Quick Sort, which is known for its efficiency on average, but has a worst-case time complexity of O(n^2) in certain scenarios. To mitigate the risk of Dual Pivot Quick Sort's worst-case behavior, Smooth Heap Sort monitors the recursion depth during the sorting process. If the depth exceeds a certain threshold, the algorithm switches to HeapSort, which guarantees worst-case O(n log(n)) time complexity but has higher overhead. Additionally, for small subarrays, Intro switches to Smooth Heap Sort, which has good performance for small input sizes.
Since:
1.0

  • Constructor Details

    • IntroDPQSmoothHeap

      public IntroDPQSmoothHeap()
      IntroDPQ (Dual Pivot Quick) Smooth Heap Sort:
      Is a hybrid sorting algorithm that combines the strengths of Dual Pivot Quick Sort and Smooth Heap Sort. It aims to provide fast average-case performance while maintaining worst-case guarantees. The basic idea behind Intro Sort is to start with Dual Pivot Quick Sort, which is known for its efficiency on average, but has a worst-case time complexity of O(n^2) in certain scenarios.

      To mitigate the risk of Dual Pivot Quick Sort's worst-case behavior, Smooth Heap Sort monitors the recursion depth during the sorting process. If the depth exceeds a certain threshold, the algorithm switches to HeapSort, which guarantees worst-case O(n log(n)) time complexity but has higher overhead. Additionally, for small subarrays, Intro switches to Smooth Heap Sort, which has good performance for small input sizes.

      Example:
      1. It checks if the size of the sub-array length is larger than INTRO_SIZE. If it is, it proceeds with the intro sort algorithm. If not, it uses insertion sort to sort the sub-array.
      2. If the maximum recursion depth is 0, it directly to sort the sub-array using a Intro Smooth Heap sorting algorithm. This is a base case to prevent excessive recursion.
      3. If the sub-array size is larger than INTRO_SIZE and the maximum recursion depth is not 0, it performs the following steps:
        • Partition the sub-array and obtain the pivot indices.
        • Recursively on the three sub-arrays:
          • From left to elements smaller than the first pivot
          • From elements between the two pivots
          • From elements greater than the second pivot
        • The recursion depth is decremented by 1 in each recursive call.
      4. If the sub-array size is smaller or equal to INTRO_SIZE, perform insertion sort on the sub-array.
      Note:
      Recursively applies the intro sort algorithm to sort a given array. It switches to insertion sort when the sub-array size becomes small enough. The maximum recursion depth is used to limit the depth of recursion to prevent excessive stack usage.

      Property:
      Worst Case Complexity: O(n^2)
      Best Case Complexity: O(n log(n))
      Average Case Complexity: O(n log(n))
      Auxiliary Space: O(log(n))
      Stability: No
